bibl.title: Iwamatus Matsuro v. T.W. Lynch. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
In the Matter of the Application of IWAMATSU MUTSURO For a WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
T.W. LYNCH, Acting Commissioner of Immigration Respondent.
Comes now IWAMATSU MUTSURO, by his attorney, Winter S. Martin, and respectfully shows to the court:

That your petitioner came to the United States on board the Japanese steamship Kenkon Maru; that he landed in the United States at the City of Seattle on October 10, 1917; that he left his ship and without passport or permission to remain in the United States continued to remain in the State of Washington until the 3rd day of November, 1921, when he was taken into custody by the United States Immigration Officers.

That on November 5, 1921, warrant of arrest for petitioner's deportation was issuede by the Secretary of Labor upon the ground that he was unlawfully in the United States in violation of immigration rule 11, which deals with the president's

proclamation under the so-called "gentlemen's agreement" between the United States and Japan; that a hearing was held upon said warrant of deportation at Seattle, aforesaid, and the findings of the immigration officers forwarded to the Commissioner General of Immigration at Washington, D.C. That thereupon by order of the Secretary of Labor your petitioner was ordered deported upon the ground that he was unlawfully in the United States in violation of immigration rule 11, under the presidential proclamation touching the "gentlemen's agreement" between Japan and the United States.

That in truth and in fact your petitioner had by lapse of time and continuous residence within the United States acquired the status of an alien under rule 19; who had entered the United States by water at a time and place other than as designated by immigration officials and had remained more than three years in said United States. And under Section 34 of the immigration laws of the United States, to-wit: Act of February 5, 1917, your petitioner was an alien seaman who had landed in the United States and had remained more than his period of three years and that by reason of the premises could not lawfully be deported.
That your petitioner by his status of more than three years in the United States had acquired such a lawful domicile as has since and now entitles him to remain in the United States.

That pursuant to the order of deportation, your petitioner, who since his arrest and detention has been held at the United States Immigration Detention Station at Seattle, will be deported by the immigration authorities at said port, to-wit:

That unless the acting commissioner of immigration and his deputies are forthwith restrained and enjoined under this application from deporting your petitioner, your petitioner will be placed upon board a ship which sails tomorrow, to-wit: November 26th, from the port of Seattle to Japan. That in all respects his arrest, detention and imprisonment is illegal and without warrant or authority.
1. That a Writ of Habeas Corpus may be issued to your said petitioner and that he may be discharged from said illegal restraint and unlawful arrest;

2. Tha pending a hearing upon an application for this Writ of Habeas Corpus that said Thomas W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, and his deputies, be hereby enjoined and restrained from deporting your petitioner from Seattle to the Empire of Japan;

3. That an order to show cause issue forthwith directed to the said Thomas W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, requiring him to be and appear in the above entitled court, at a time to be fixed by this Honorable Court, to show cause, if any he has, why the said Writ of Habeas Corpus shall not be granted.
United States of America, Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
IWAMATSU MUTSURO, being first duly sworn by and through an interpreter, upon his oath states:
That he has heard read to him this Petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, and that the facts therein stated are true.
SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN to before me this 25th day of November, 1921.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
Filed in the United States District Court
